title: ProLog
tagline: A journey companion for neurodivergent apprentices
subtitle: A journey companion for neurodivergent apprentices
summary: A centralized apprenticeship companion helping neurodivergent apprentices track progress, reduce cognitive overload, and build confidence through clear visualization and structured tools.

overview.title: Overview
overview.description:
Apprenticeship can take over 6,000 hours. That's years of work, spread across job sites, classrooms, and bureaucratic systems—often without a clear sense of whether you're on track.

Early in our research, we kept hearing the same thing: confusion was pushing people out. Not inability. Not lack of motivation. Just confusion about where they stood and what came next.

We wanted to build something that answered one question clearly: Where am I right now?

problem.title: The Problem
problem.description:
Apprentices in British Columbia navigate a surprisingly fragmented system. Hours are logged in one place, competencies tracked in another, and certification requirements buried in dense PDFs.

For neurotypical users, this is frustrating. For neurodivergent apprentices—who may already struggle with executive function, time blindness, or information overload—it becomes a genuine barrier to completion.

The system wasn't designed to be hostile. It just wasn't designed with these users in mind.

research.title: Research & Insights
research.description:
We conducted policy and documentation review (SkilledTradesBC), stakeholder conversations with industry partners, persona development based on lived experience, and team reflection sessions (our team included neurodivergent members).

Key findings: Progress tracking is scattered across multiple platforms with no single source of truth. Official systems are desktop-first and difficult to use on job sites. Discrepancies between employer-logged and self-logged hours create anxiety. Neurodivergent users experience amplified cognitive load from inconsistent interfaces.

We didn't have access to a large participant pool, so we leaned into what we did have: our own team's lived experience, publicly available documentation, and honest conversations with stakeholders.

challenges.title: Early Challenges
challenges.description:
This project started too big. We wanted to fix financial stress, employer communication, exam preparation, and progress tracking—all at once. Our advisor encouraged broad exploration, which felt productive at first but eventually led to paralysis.

It wasn't until we accepted that we couldn't solve everything that the project started moving. Narrowing our focus to neurodivergent apprentices gave us permission to go deeper instead of wider.

pivots.reason: A narrower scope allowed us to design with real empathy instead of generic assumptions

lofi.title: Lo-Fi Exploration
lofi.description:
Our early sketches were deliberately rough. We weren't trying to make things look good—we were trying to understand what information mattered most and how quickly someone could find it.

The dashboard concept emerged early. We kept asking ourselves: if an apprentice opens this app on a break, what should they see in the first three seconds?

Progress bars, hour counts, and next-step prompts became the core. Everything else was secondary.

iterations.title: High-Fidelity Designs
iterations.description:
The high-fidelity designs prioritized calm. We chose soft colors, generous spacing, and typography that wouldn't feel clinical or overwhelming.

The dashboard became the emotional center of the app. Instead of hiding progress behind menus, we made it the first thing users see. Hours completed, hours remaining, competencies achieved—all visible at a glance.
improvements: Prioritized calm through soft colors and generous spacing
Made dashboard the emotional center with immediate progress visibility
Used clear typography to avoid clinical or overwhelming feel
Designed for offline-first architecture for job site use
Created discrepancy detection for hour tracking

solution.title: Final Solution
solution.description: ProLog provides four core features: a Progress Dashboard that acts as a GPS for the apprenticeship journey, an Hours Discrepancy Detector that compares user-logged hours against official records, a Financial Resources Hub with links to grants and funding programs, and AI Practice Quizzes that generate unique practice questions based on trade competencies.

features.title: Progress Dashboard
features.description: A centralized view of hours completed, hours remaining, competencies achieved, and certification progress. No digging required—the answer to 'where am I?' is always visible.

features.title: Hours Discrepancy Detector
features.description: Compares user-logged hours against official records and flags mismatches. Users can document discrepancies and generate reports for their employers.

features.title: Financial Resources Hub
features.description: Links to grants, funding programs, and itemized cost breakdowns for apprenticeship expenses.

features.title: AI Practice Quizzes
features.description: Generates unique practice questions based on trade competencies. Designed to build confidence before official exams.

validation.title: Validation & Testing
validation.description: We tested the prototype with a small group and heard something we didn't expect: relief. Users described the dashboard as a 'GPS for my apprenticeship.' They appreciated that they didn't have to hunt for information—it was just there. The hours tracker resonated especially strongly. One participant said they'd never realized they could document discrepancies themselves.

insights.title: Clarity is an emotional outcome
insights.description: When users said they felt 'relieved,' they were responding to design decisions—not just information architecture.

insights.title: Scope control is a design skill
insights.description: Saying no to good ideas was harder than coming up with them.

insights.title: Progress visualization restores motivation
insights.description: Seeing how far you've come matters as much as knowing what's next.

insights.title: Qualitative feedback is valid
insights.description: In student work, we don't always have access to large sample sizes. That doesn't make insights less real.

nextSteps.title: Next Steps
items: Pursue data partnerships with SkilledTradesBC to enable real-time syncing
Expand accessibility features including screen reader optimization and high-contrast modes
Develop offline-friendly experiences for use on job sites with limited connectivity

outcomes.title: Impact & Reflection
outcomes.description: Apprentices can quickly understand progress and next steps. Modular design allows future expansion to additional trades and certifications. Collaboration strengthened by research and iterative design process. Editorial layout and visual progress tracking increase engagement and motivation. Lessons learned: Visual progress indicators are essential for user motivation. Clear language reduces confusion. Whitespace and editorial design improve content hierarchy and readability.
